column318: including 3.0% of those under age 18 and 2.9% of those age 65 or over.<ref name=Census2000/><ref name=Census2000SF1/>==Government=====Local government===Chatham Township is governed under the [[Township (New Jersey)|township]] form of government with a five-member Township Committee. The Township Committee is elected directly by the voters [[at-large]] in partisan elections to serve three-year terms of office on a staggered basis
column319: with either one or two seats coming up for election each year as part of the November general election in a three-year cycle.<ref name=DataBook>''2012 New Jersey Legislative District Data Book''
column320: [[Rutgers University]] [[Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy]]
column323: the Township Committee selects one of its members to serve as mayor. The ceremonial mayor serves as the chair of the township committee and has powers vested in the mayor's office by general law.The township committee is the legislative branch of the community's government and establishes policies for the administration of the various departments. The committee appoints the township administrator who is responsible for carrying out those policies and overseeing the day-to-day operations. Subcommittees of the township committee are public safety. public works. planning
column325: and land use. parks and recreation. general administration. and finance. Two members of the township committee serve on each and provide oversight to the departments.<ref>[http://www.chathamtownship-nj.gov/Form_of_Government.html Form of Government]
column328: members of the Chatham Township Committee are [[Mayor]] Kevin Sullivan ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]

column12: 12883|area_code                = [[Area code 518|518]]|blank_name               = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]]|blank_info               = 36-73891|blank1_name              = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID|blank1_info              = 0979547|website                  =|footnotes                =}}'''Ticonderoga''' is a [[Administrative divisions of New York#Town|town]] in [[Essex County
column16: 042 at the 2010 census. The name comes from the [[Mohawk language|Mohawk]] ''tekontaró:ken''
column17: meaning""it is at the junction of two waterways"".<ref>Afable
column18: Patricia O. and Madison S. Beeler (1996).""Place Names""
column20: ed. Ives Goddard. Vol. 17 of ''Handbook of North American Indians''
column23: p. 193</ref>The town of Ticonderoga is in the southeastern part of the county and is south of [[Plattsburgh (city)
column26: NY.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Fort Ticonderoga]] located on the east side of town on [[New York State Route 74|NY&nbsp.74]]]]The crossing between Lakes [[Lake George (New York)|George]] and [[Lake Champlain|Champlain]] had been used by natives for thousands of years.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} In the 17th century
column27: French explorers such as [[Samuel de Champlain]] explored the area.The town was located on the direct route
column28: utilizing rivers and two long lakes
column29: between [[New York City]] to the south and the French settlement of [[Montreal]] to the north. The town was the setting for historic battles and maneuvers during both the [[French and Indian War]] and the [[American Revolutionary War]]. [[Fort Ticonderoga]]
column33: marked the location of an important [[portage]] between the two lakes.The town of Ticonderoga was formed in 1804 from part of the town of [[Crown Point
column34: New York|Crown Point]]. By the end of the 18th Century
column35: the town was noted for wood products such as paper and lead pencils. The position of the now former Ticonderoga [[Administrative divisions of New York#Village|village]] at the north end of [[Lake George (New York)|Lake George]] made it an important port.Historical Fort Ticonderoga is in this town
column36: east of the former village of [[Ticonderoga (hamlet)
column37: New York|Ticonderoga]].==Geography==According to the [[United States Census Bureau]]
column38: the town has a total area of {{convert|88.3|sqmi|km2}}
column40: {{convert|81.8|sqmi|km2}} is land and {{convert|6.5|sqmi|km2}}(7.36%) is water.The town borders both north end of [[Lake George (New York)|Lake George]] and south end of [[Lake Champlain]]. The short
column42: La Chute River connects the two lakes. The east town line is the border of [[Vermont]]
column43: and the south town line is the county line of [[Warren County
column45: New York|Washington County]].[[New York State Route 9N]] is a north-south highway. Another north-south highway
column47: is partly conjoined with NY-9N in the town. [[New York State Route 74]]
column48: an east-west highway intersects NY-9N/NY-22 near Ticonderoga village.==Demographics==[[File:Black Watch Library

column1: Lambda calculus"; lambda calculus found early successes in the area of [[computability theory]]
column2: such as a negative answer to [[David Hilbert|Hilbert]]'s [[Entscheidungsproblem]]. Lambda calculus is a conceptually simple [[Turing completeness|universal model of computation]] (Turing showed in 1937<ref>{{cite journal |first=A. M. |last=Turing |title=Computability and λ-Definability |jstor=2268280 |journal=The Journal of Symbolic Logic |volume=2 |issue=4 |date=December 1937 |pages=153–163 |doi=10.2307/2268280}}</ref>that [[Turing machine]]s equated{{what|reason=equalled?|date=May 2015}} the lambda calculus in expressiveness). The name derives from the Greek letter lambda (λ) used to denote [[Free variables and bound variables|binding]] a variable in a function. The letter itself is arbitrary and has no special meaning. Lambda calculus is taught and used in computer science because of its usefulness in showcasing functional thinking and iterative reduction.<ref>{{citation|title=Concepts in Programming Languages|first=John C.|last=Mitchell|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2003|isbn=9780521780988|page=57|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7Uh8XGfJbEIC&pg=PA57}}.</ref>Because of the importance of the notion of variable binding and substitution
column3: there is not just one system of lambda calculus
column4: and in particular there are ''typed'' and ''untyped'' variants. Historically
column5: the most important system was the untyped lambda calculus
column6: in which function application has no restrictions (so the notion of the [[domain of a function]] is not built into the system). In the [[Church–Turing thesis|Church&ndash.Turing Thesis]]
column7: the untyped lambda calculus is claimed to be capable of computing all [[effective method|effectively calculable]] functions. The typed lambda calculus is a variety that restricts function application
column8: so that functions can only be applied if they are capable of accepting the given input's""type""of data.Today
column9: the lambda calculus has applications in many different areas in [[mathematics]]
column16: <ref>{{Citation|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9CdFE9X_FCoC |title=Categorial Investigations: Logical and Linguistic Aspects of the Lambek Calculus - Michael Moortgat - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= 1988-01-01|accessdate=2013-09-15|isbn=9789067653879}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nyFa5ngYThMC |title=Computing Meaning - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= 2008-07-02|accessdate=2013-09-15|isbn=9781402059575}}</ref>and computer science. It is still used in the area of computability theory
column17: although Turing machines are also an important model for computation. Lambda calculus has played an important role in the development of the [[Programming language theory|theory of programming languages]]. Counterparts to lambda calculus in computer science are [[functional programming language]]s
column18: which essentially implement the lambda calculus (augmented with some [[Constant (programming)|constants]] and [[datatype]]s). Beyond programming languages
column19: the lambda calculus also has many applications in [[proof theory]]. A major example of this is the [[Curry&ndash.Howard correspondence]]
column20: which gives a correspondence between different systems of typed lambda calculus and systems of [[formal logic]].==Lambda calculus in history of mathematics==The lambda calculus was introduced by mathematician [[Alonzo Church]] in the 1930s as part of an investigation into the [[foundations of mathematics]].<ref>A. Church
column21: A set of postulates for the foundation of logic""
column25: see Cardone and Hindley's""History of Lambda-calculus and Combinatory Logic""(2006).</ref>The original system was shown to be [[Consistency|logically inconsistent]] in 1935 when [[Stephen Kleene]] and [[J. B. Rosser]] developed the [[Kleene&ndash.Rosser paradox]].Subsequently
column26: in 1936 Church isolated and published just the portion relevant to computation
column27: what is now called the untyped lambda calculus.<ref>A. Church
column28: An unsolvable problem of elementary number theory""
column33: he also introduced a computationally weaker
column35: known as the [[simply typed lambda calculus]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Church | first1 = A. | year = | title = A Formulation of the Simple Theory of Types | url = | journal = Journal of Symbolic Logic | volume = 5 | issue = | page = 1940 | doi=10.2307/2266170}}</ref>==Informal description=={{no footnotes|section|date=September 2013}}===Motivation===[[Computable function]]s are a fundamental concept within computer science and mathematics. The λ-calculus provides a simple [[Semantics#Computer science|semantics]] for computation
column36: enabling properties of computation to be studied formally. The λ-calculus incorporates two simplifications that make this semantics simple.The first simplification is that the λ-calculus treats functions""anonymously""
column37: without giving them explicit names. For example
column39: y) = x \times x + y \times y</math>can be rewritten in ''anonymous form'' as:<math>(x
column40: y) \mapsto x \times x + y \times y</math>(read as""the pair of<math>x</math>and<math>y</math>is [[Map (disambiguation)#Mathematics and programming|mapped]] to<math>x \times x + y \times y</math>""). Similarly
column41: :<math>\operatorname{id}(x) = x</math>can be rewritten in anonymous form as<math>x \mapsto x</math>
column42: where the input is simply mapped to itself.The second simplification is that the λ-calculus only uses functions of a single input. An ordinary function that requires two inputs
column44: can be reworked into an equivalent function that accepts a single input
column46: that in turn accepts a single input. For example
column48: y) \mapsto x \times x + y \times y</math>can be reworked into:<math>x \mapsto (y \mapsto x \times x + y \times y)</math>This method
column50: transforms a function that takes multiple arguments into a chain of functions each with a single argument.[[Function application]] of the<math>\operatorname{sqsum}</math>function to the arguments (5
column55: whereas evaluation of the curried version requires one more step:<math>((x \mapsto (y \mapsto x \times x + y \times y))(5))(2)</math>:<math>= (y \mapsto 5 \times 5 + y \times y)(2)</math>:<math>= 5 \times 5 + 2 \times 2</math>:<math>= 29</math>to arrive at the same result.===The lambda calculus===The lambda calculus consists of a language of '''lambda terms'''
column56: which is defined by a certain formal syntax
column57: and a set of transformation rules
column58: which allow manipulation of the lambda terms. These transformation rules can be viewed as an equational theory or as an [[operational definition]].As described above
column59: all functions in the lambda calculus are anonymous functions
column60: having no names. They only accept one input variable
column61: with currying used to implement functions with several variables.====Lambda terms====The syntax of the lambda calculus defines some expressions as valid lambda calculus expression and some as invalid
column62: just as some strings of characters are valid [[C (programming language)|C]] programs and some are not. A valid lambda calculus expression is called a""lambda term"".The following three rules give an [[inductive definition]] that can be applied to build all syntactically valid lambda terms:* a variable
column64: is itself a valid lambda term* if<math>t</math>is a lambda term
column66: then<math>(\lambda x.t)</math>is a lambda term (called a '''lambda abstraction''').* if<math>t</math>and<math>s</math>are lambda terms
column67: then<math>(ts)</math>is a lambda term (called an '''application''').Nothing else is a lambda term. Thus a lambda term is valid if and only if it can be obtained by repeated application of these three rules. However
column68: some parentheses can be omitted according to certain rules. For example
column69: the outermost parentheses are usually not written. ''See'' [[#Notation]]
column70: below.A '''lambda abstraction'''<math>\lambda x.t</math>is a definition of an anonymous function that is capable of taking a single input<math>x</math>and substituting it into the expression<math>t</math>.It thus defines an anonymous function that takes x and returns t. For example<math>\lambda x.x^2+2</math>is a lambda abstraction for the function<math>f(x) = x^2 + 2</math>using the term<math>x^2+2</math>for<math>t</math>. The definition of a function with a lambda abstraction merely""sets up""the function but does not invoke it.  The abstraction [[Free variables and bound variables|binds]] the variable<math>x</math>in the term<math>t</math>.An '''application'''<math>ts</math>represents the application of a function<math>t</math>to an input<math>s</math>
column72: it represents the act of calling function<math>t</math>on input<math>s</math>to produce<math>t(s)</math>.There is no concept in lambda calculus of variable declaration. In a definition such as<math>\lambda x.x+y</math>(i.e.<math>f(x) = x + y</math>)
column73: the lambda calculus treats<math>y</math>as a variable that is not yet defined. The lambda abstraction<math>\lambda x.x+y</math>is syntactically valid
column74: and represents a function that adds its input to the yet-unknown<math>y</math>.Bracketing may be used and may be needed to disambiguate terms. For example
column75: <math>\lambda x.((\lambda x.x)x)</math>and<math>(\lambda x.(\lambda x.x)) x</math>denote different terms (although coincidentally reduce to the same value.)==== Functions that operate on functions ====In lambda calculus
column76: functions are taken to be '[[First-class object|first class values]]'
column77: so functions may be used as the inputs
column78: or be returned as outputs from other functions.For example
column81: and<math>(\lambda x.x)y</math>represents the identity function applied to<math>y</math>. Further
column84: no matter the input. In lambda calculus
column85: function application is regarded as [[Operator associativity|left-associative]]
column86: so that<math>stx</math>means<math>(st)x</math>.There are several notions of""equivalence""and""reduction""that allow lambda terms to be""reduced""to""equivalent""lambda terms.====Alpha equivalence====A basic form of equivalence
column88: is alpha equivalence. It captures the intuition that the particular choice of a bound variable
column92: and they both represent the same function (the identity function).The terms<math>x</math>and<math>y</math>are not alpha-equivalent
column93: because they are not bound in a lambda abstraction.In many presentations
column94: it is usual to identify alpha-equivalent lambda terms.The following definitions are necessary in order to be able to define beta reduction.====Free variables====The '''free variables''' of a term are those variables not bound by a lambda abstraction. The set of free variables of an expression is defined inductively:* The free variables of<math>x</math>are just<math>x</math>* The set of free variables of<math>\lambda x.t</math>is the set of free variables of<math>t</math>
column95: but with<math>x</math>removed* The set of free variables of<math>ts</math>is the union of the set of free variables of<math>t</math>and the set of free variables of<math>s</math>.For example
column96: the lambda term representing the identity<math>\lambda x.x</math>has no free variables
column97: but the function<math>\lambda x.x+y</math>has a single free variable
column99: <math>s</math>and<math>r</math>are lambda terms and<math>x</math>and<math>y</math>are variables.The notation<math>t[x := r]</math>indicates substitution of<math>r</math>for<math>x</math>in<math>t</math>in a ''capture-avoiding'' manner. This is defined so that:*<math>x[x := r] = r</math>.*<math>y[x := r] = y</math>if<math>x \neq y</math>.*<math>(ts)[x := r] = (t[x := r])(s[x := r])</math>.*<math>(\lambda x.t)[x := r] = \lambda x.t</math>.*<math>(\lambda y.t)[x := r] = \lambda y.(t[x := r])</math>if<math>x \neq y</math>and<math>y</math>is not in the free variables of<math>r</math>. The variable<math>y</math>is said to be""fresh""for<math>r</math>.For example
column101: and<math>((\lambda x.y)x)[x := y] = ((\lambda x.y)[x := y])(x[x := y]) = (\lambda x.y)y</math>.The freshness condition (requiring that<math>y</math>is not in the free variables of<math>r</math>)  is crucial in order to ensure that substitution does not change the meaning of functions.For example
column102: a substitution is made that ignores  the freshness condition:<math>(\lambda x.y)[y := x] = \lambda x.(y[y := x]) = \lambda x.x</math>. This substitution turns the constant function<math>\lambda x.y</math>into the identity<math>\lambda x.x</math>by substitution.In general
column103: failure to meet the freshness condition can be remedied by alpha-renaming with a suitable fresh variable.For example
column104: switching back to our correct notion of substitution
column105: in<math>(\lambda y.x)[x := y]</math>the lambda abstraction can be renamed with a fresh variable<math>z</math>
column106: to obtain<math>(\lambda z.x)[x := y] = \lambda z.(x[x := y]) = \lambda z.y</math>
column107: and the meaning of the function is preserved by substitution.====Beta reduction====The beta reduction rule states that an application of the form<math>( \lambda x . t) s</math>reduces to the term<math>t [ x := s]</math>. The notation<math>( \lambda x . t ) s \to t [ x := s ]</math>is used to indicate that<math>( \lambda x .t ) s</math>beta reduces to<math>t [ x := s ]</math>.For example
column109: <math>( \lambda x . x ) s \to x[ x := s ] = s</math>. This demonstrates that<math>\lambda x . x</math>really is the identity.Similarly
column110: <math>( \lambda x . y ) s \to y [ x := s ] = y</math>
column111: which demonstrates that<math>\lambda x . y</math>is a constant function.The lambda calculus may be seen as an idealised functional programming language
column112: like [[Haskell (programming language)|Haskell]] or [[Standard ML]].Under this view
column113: beta reduction corresponds to a computational step. This step can be repeated by additional beta conversions until there are no more applications left to reduce. In the untyped lambda calculus
column115: this reduction process may not terminate.For instance
column116: consider the term<math>( \lambda x . xx)( \lambda x . xx )</math>.Here<math>( \lambda x . xx)( \lambda x . xx) \to ( xx )[ x := \lambda x . xx ] = ( x [ x := \lambda x . xx ] )( x [ x := \lambda x . xx ] ) = ( \lambda x . xx)( \lambda x . xx )</math>.That is
column117: the term reduces to itself in a single beta reduction
column118: and therefore the reduction process will never terminate.Another aspect of the untyped lambda calculus is that it does not distinguish between different kinds of data.For instance
column119: it may be desirable to write a function that only operates on numbers. However
column121: there is no way to prevent a function from being applied to [[truth value]]s
column123: or other non-number objects.==Formal definition=====Definition===Lambda expressions are composed of* variables v<sub>1</sub>
column127: ...* the abstraction symbols lambda 'λ' and dot '.'* parentheses ( )The set of lambda expressions
column129: can be [[Recursive definition|defined inductively]]:#If x is a variable
column130: then x ∈ Λ#If x is a variable and M ∈ Λ
column133: then (M N) ∈ ΛInstances of rule 2 are known as abstractions and instances of rule 3 are known as applications.<ref>{{Citation| last = Barendregt| first = Hendrik Pieter| author-link =| last2 =| first2 =| author2-link =| title = The Lambda Calculus: Its Syntax and Semantics| place =| publisher = North Holland
column134: Amsterdam. [ftp://ftp.cs.ru.nl/pub/CompMath.Found/ErrataLCalculus.pdf Corrections]| year = 1984| volume = 103| series = Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics| edition = Revised| url = http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/bookdescription.cws_home/501727/description| doi =| id =| isbn = 0-444-87508-5}}</ref>===Notation===To keep the notation of lambda expressions uncluttered
column135: the following conventions are usually applied.* Outermost parentheses are dropped: M N instead of (M N)* Applications are assumed to be left associative: M N P may be written instead of ((M N) P)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lambda-bound.com/book/lambdacalc/node27.html |title=Example for Rules of Associativity |publisher=Lambda-bound.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-18}}</ref>* The body of an abstraction extends [[Regular expression#Lazy quantification|as far right as possible]]: λx.M N means λx.(M N) and not (λx.M) N* A sequence of abstractions is contracted: λx.λy.λz.N is abbreviated as λxyz.N<ref name=""Selinger"">{{Citation| first = Peter| last = Selinger| author-link =| title = Lecture Notes on the Lambda Calculus| year =2008| page = 9| place =| publisher = Department of Mathematics and Statistics
column136: University of Ottawa| url = http://www.mathstat.dal.ca/~selinger/papers/lambdanotes.pdf| bibcode = 2008arXiv0804.3434S| volume = 0804| arxiv = 0804.3434| issue=class: cs.LO }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lambda-bound.com/book/lambdacalc/node25.html |title=Example for Rule of Associativity |publisher=Lambda-bound.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-18}}</ref>===Free and bound variables===The abstraction operator
column138: is said to bind its variable wherever it occurs in the body of the abstraction. Variables that fall within the scope of an abstraction are said to be ''bound''. All other variables are called ''free''. For example
column139: in the following expression y is a bound variable and x is free:<tt>λ''y''.''x'' ''x'' ''y''</tt>. Also note that a variable is bound by its""nearest""abstraction. In the following example the single occurrence of x in the expression is bound by the second lambda:<tt>λ''x''.''y''  (λ''x''.''z'' ''x'')</tt>The set of ''free variables'' of a lambda expression
column141: is denoted as FV(M) and is defined by recursion on the structure of the terms
column143: where x is a variable# FV(λx.M) = FV(M) \ {x}# FV(M N) = FV(M) ∪ FV(N)<ref name=""BarendregtBarendsen"">{{Citation| last = Barendregt| first = Henk| author-link =| last2 = Barendsen| first2 = Erik| author2-link =| title = Introduction to Lambda Calculus| place =| publisher =| year = March 2000| volume =| edition =| url = ftp://ftp.cs.ru.nl/pub/CompMath.Found/lambda.pdf| doi =| id =| isbn = }}</ref>An expression that contains no free variables is said to be ''closed''. Closed lambda expressions are also known as combinators and are equivalent to terms in [[combinatory logic]].==Reduction==The meaning of lambda expressions is defined by how expressions can be reduced.<ref>[[Ruy de Queiroz |de Queiroz
column144: Ruy J.G.B.]]""[http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1746-8361.1988.tb00919.x A Proof-Theoretic Account of Programming and the Role of Reduction Rules.]""''Dialectica'' '''42'''(4)
column146: 1988.</ref>There are three kinds of reduction:* '''α-conversion''': changing bound variables ('''alpha''').* '''β-reduction''': applying functions to their arguments ('''beta''').* '''η-conversion''': which captures a notion of extensionality ('''eta''').We also speak of the resulting equivalences: two expressions are ''β-equivalent''
column147: if they can be β-converted into the same expression
column148: and α/η-equivalence are defined similarly.The term ''redex''
column150: refers to subterms that can be reduced by one of the reduction rules. For example
column151: <tt>(λ''x''.M) N</tt>is a beta-redex in expressing the substitution of N for x in M. if<tt>''x''</tt>is not free in<tt>M</tt>
column152: <tt>λ''x''.M ''x''</tt>is an eta-redex. The expression to which a redex reduces is called its reduct. using the previous example
column153: the reducts of these expressions are respectively<tt>M[''x'':=N]</tt>and<tt>M</tt>.===α-conversion===Alpha-conversion
column155: <ref>{{Citation |title=Design concepts in programming languages |last1=Turbak |first1=Franklyn |last2=Gifford |first2=David |year=2008 |publisher=MIT press |page=251| isbn=978-0-262-20175-9}}</ref>allows bound variable names to be changed. For example
column156: alpha-conversion of<tt>λ''x''.''x''</tt>might yield<tt>λ''y''.''y''</tt>. Terms that differ only by alpha-conversion are called ''α-equivalent''. Frequently
column158: α-equivalent terms are considered to be equivalent.The precise rules for alpha-conversion are not completely trivial. First
column160: the only variable occurrences that are renamed are those that are bound to the same abstraction. For example
column162: but it could ''not'' result in<tt>λ''y''.λ''x''.''y''</tt>. The latter has a different meaning from the original.Second
column163: alpha-conversion is not possible if it would result in a variable getting captured by a different abstraction. For example
column166: which is not at all the same.In programming languages with static scope
column167: alpha-conversion can be used to make [[name resolution]] simpler by ensuring that no variable name [[Variable shadowing|masks]] a name in a containing [[scope (programming)|scope]] (see [[Name resolution#Alpha renaming to make name resolution trivial|alpha renaming to make name resolution trivial]]).In the [[De Bruijn index]] notation
column168: any two alpha-equivalent terms are literally identical.====Substitution====Substitution
column170: is the process of replacing all free occurrences of the variable<tt>''V''</tt>in the expression<tt>''E''</tt>with expression<tt>''R''</tt>.Substitution on terms of the λ-calculus is defined by recursion on the structure of terms
column171: as follows (note: x and y are only variables while M and N are any λ expression).:<tt>''x''[''x'' := N]&nbsp.&nbsp.&nbsp.&nbsp.&nbsp.&nbsp.&equiv. N</tt>:<tt>''y''[''x'' := N]&nbsp.&nbsp.&nbsp.&nbsp.&nbsp.&nbsp.&equiv. ''y''
column172: if ''x'' ≠ ''y''</tt>:<tt>(M<sub>1</sub>M<sub>2</sub>)[''x'' := N]&nbsp.&nbsp.&equiv. (M<sub>1</sub>[''x'' := N]) (M<sub>2</sub>[''x'' := N])</tt>:<tt>(λ''x''.M)[''x'' := N]&nbsp.&equiv. λ''x''.M</tt>:<tt>(λ''y''.M)[''x'' := N]&nbsp.&equiv. λ''y''.(M[''x'' := N])
column174: ''provided'' ''y'' ∉ FV(N)</tt>To substitute into a lambda abstraction
column175: it is sometimes necessary to α-convert the expression. For example
column176: it is not correct for<tt>(λ''x''.''y'')[''y'' := ''x'']</tt>to result in<tt>(λ''x''.''x'')</tt>
column177: because the substituted<tt>''x''</tt>was supposed to be free but ended up being bound. The correct substitution in this case is<tt>(λ''z''.''x'')</tt>
column178: up to α-equivalence. Notice that substitution is defined uniquely up to α-equivalence.===&beta.-reduction===Beta-reduction captures the idea of function application. Beta-reduction is defined in terms of substitution: the beta-reduction of<tt>&nbsp.((λ''V''.''E'') ''E&prime.'')&nbsp.</tt>is<tt>''E''[''V'' := ''E&prime.'']</tt>.For example
column182: we have the following β-reduction:<tt>((λ''n''.''n''&times.2) 7)</tt>→<tt>7&times.2</tt>.===&eta.-conversion===Eta-conversion expresses the idea of [[extensionality]]
column183: which in this context is that two functions are the same [[if and only if]] they give the same result for all arguments. Eta-conversion converts between<tt>λ''x''.(''f'' ''x'')</tt>and<tt>''f''</tt>whenever<tt>''x''</tt>does not appear free in<tt>''f''</tt>.== Normal forms and confluence =={{Main|Normalization property (abstract rewriting)}}For the untyped lambda calculus
column184: β-reduction as a [[rewrite system|rewriting rule]] is neither [[strongly normalising]] nor [[weakly normalising]].However
column185: it can be shown that β-reduction is [[confluence (abstract rewriting)|confluent]]. (Of course
column186: we are working up to α-conversion
column187: i.e. we consider two normal forms to be equal
column188: if it is possible to α-convert one into the other.)Therefore
column189: both strongly normalising terms and weakly normalising terms have a unique normal form. For strongly normalising terms
column190: any reduction strategy is guaranteed to yield the normal form
column192: some reduction strategies may fail to find it.==Encoding datatypes=={{Main|Church encoding|Mogensen–Scott encoding}}The basic lambda calculus may be used to model booleans
column195: as illustrated in the following sub-sections.===Arithmetic in lambda calculus===There are several possible ways to define the [[natural number]]s in lambda calculus
column196: but by far the most common are the [[Church numeral]]s
column197: which can be defined as follows::<tt>0 := λ''f''.λ''x''.''x''</tt>:<tt>1 := λ''f''.λ''x''.''f'' ''x''</tt>:<tt>2 := λ''f''.λ''x''.''f'' (''f'' ''x'')</tt>:<tt>3 := λ''f''.λ''x''.''f'' (''f'' (''f'' ''x''))</tt>and so on. Or using the alternative syntax presented above in ''[[#Notation|Notation]]''::<tt>0 := λ''fx''.''x''</tt>:<tt>1 := λ''fx''.''f'' ''x''</tt>:<tt>2 := λ''fx''.''f'' (''f'' ''x'')</tt>:<tt>3 := λ''fx''.''f'' (''f'' (''f'' ''x''))</tt>A Church numeral is a [[higher-order function]]—it takes a single-argument function<tt>''f''</tt>
column198: and returns another single-argument function. The Church numeral<tt>''n''</tt>is a function that takes a function<tt>''f''</tt>as argument and returns the<tt>''n''</tt>-th composition of<tt>''f''</tt>
column199: i.e. the function<tt>''f''</tt>composed with itself<tt>''n''</tt>times. This is denoted<tt>''f''<sup>(''n'')</sup></tt>and is in fact the<tt>''n''</tt>-th power of<tt>''f''</tt>(considered as an operator).<tt>''f''<sup>(0)</sup></tt>is defined to be the identity function. Such repeated compositions (of a single function<tt>''f''</tt>) obey the [[laws of exponents]]

column287: types are usually objects of a syntactic nature that are assigned to lambda terms. the exact nature of a type depends on the calculus considered (see kinds below). From a certain point of view

column293: e.g. the simply typed lambda calculus is the language of [[cartesian closed category|Cartesian closed categories]] (CCCs).==Computable functions and lambda calculus==A function ''F'': '''N''' → '''N''' of natural numbers is a computable function if and only if there exists a lambda expression ''f'' such that for every pair of ''x''

This is one of the many ways to define computability. see the [[Church-Turing thesis]] for a discussion of other approaches and their equivalence.==Undecidability of equivalence==There is no algorithm that takes as input two lambda expressions and outputs<tt>TRUE</tt>or<tt>FALSE</tt>depending on whether or not the two expressions are equivalent. This was historically the first problem for which undecidability could be proven. As is common for a proof of undecidability
column298: the proof shows that no computable function can decide the equivalence. [[Church's thesis]] is then invoked to show that no algorithm can do so.Church's proof first reduces the problem to determining whether a given lambda expression has a ''normal form''. A normal form is an equivalent expression that cannot be reduced any further under the rules imposed by the form. Then he assumes that this predicate is computable

column369: 2005.</ref>offer a way of tracking the locations of free variables in expressions.===Parallelism and concurrency===The [[Church–Rosser theorem|Church–Rosser]] property of the lambda calculus means that evaluation (β-reduction) can be carried out in ''any order''

column1: Ediacaran"; named after the [[Ediacara Hills]] of [[South Australia]]
column2: is the last geological [[period (geology)|period]] of the [[Neoproterozoic]] Era and of the [[Proterozoic]] Eon
column4: the first period of the [[Paleozoic]] Era and of the [[Phanerozoic]] Eon.The Ediacaran Period's status as an official geological period was ratified in 2004 by the [[International Union of Geological Sciences]] (IUGS)
column5: making it the first new geological period declared in 120 years.<ref name=Knoll2004a/><ref name=Knoll2004>{{cite journal| author = Knoll

column15: at  {{coord|31|19|53.8|S|138|38|0.1|E|display=inline}}.==Ediacaran and Vendian==The Ediacaran Period overlaps
column16: but is shorter than the '''Vendian''' Period

column20: and the lower boundary of the Cambrian became the upper boundary of the Vendian.<ref name= Sokolov1952>{{cite journal| author = B. M. Sokolov| year = 1952| title = On the age of the old sedimentary cover of the Russian Platform| journal = Izvestiya Akademii Nauk SSSR

column57: [[metazoan]] body fossils and [[ichnofossil]]s.<ref name=Sokolov1997/><ref name=SokolovFedonkin1984>{{cite doi|10.1134/S0869593808060014}}</ref>The lower boundary of the Vendian could have a [[biostratigraphic]] substantiation as well taking into consideration the worldwide occurrence of the [[Pertatataka Formation|Pertatataka]] assemblage of giant acanthomorph [[acritarch]]s.<ref name=Fedonkin2007/>==Boundaries of the Ediacaran==[[File:Ediacaran-GSSP-IMGP6652-.jpg|thumb|250px|The 'golden spike' (bronze disk in the lower section of the image) or 'type section' of the [[Global Boundary Stratotype Section and Point]] (GSSP) for the base of Ediacaran period.]][[File:Ediacaran GSSP - closeup.JPG|thumb|The 'golden spike' marking the GSSP]][[File:Elatina Fm diamictite.JPG|thumb|Elatina Fm [[diamictite]] below Ediacaran [[Global Boundary Stratotype Section and Point|GSSP]] site in the [[Flinders Ranges National Park|Flinders Ranges NP]]
column58: South Australia. A$1 coin for scale.]]The Ediacaran Period (ca. 635-542 Mya) represents the time from the end of global [[Marinoan glaciation]] to the first appearance worldwide of somewhat complicated trace fossils (''[[Treptichnus pedum]]'' (Seilacher
column62: and N. Christie-Blick (2004)""[http://www.stratigraphy.org/bak/ediacaran/Knoll_et_al_2004a.pdf The Ediacaran Period: A New Addition to the Geologic Time Scale.]""Submitted on Behalf of the Terminal Proterozoic Subcommission of the International Commission on Stratigraphy.</ref>Although the Ediacaran Period does contain soft-bodied [[fossil]]s
column63: it is unusual in comparison to later periods because its beginning is not defined by a change in the fossil record. Rather
column64: the beginning is defined at the base of a chemically distinctive [[carbonate]] layer that is referred to as a""[[cap carbonate]]
column65: because it caps glacial deposits.This bed is characterized by an unusual depletion of<sup>13</sup>[[Carbon|C]] that indicates a sudden climatic change at the end of the [[Marinoan]] [[ice age]]. The lower boundary [[GSSP]] of the Ediacaran is at the base of the cap carbonate (Nuccaleena Formation)
column66: immediately above the Elatina [[diamictite]] in the Enorama Creek section
column69: South Australia.The [[GSSP]] of the upper boundary of the Ediacaran is the lower boundary of the Cambrian on the SE coast of Newfoundland approved by the International Commission on Stratigraphy as a preferred alternative to the base of the [[Tommotian]] Stage in [[Siberia]] which was selected on the basis of the ichnofossil ''Treptichnus pedum'' (Seilacher
column70: 1955). In the history of stratigraphy it was the first case of usage of bioturbations for the System boundary definition.Nevertheless
column71: the definitions of the lower and upper boundaries of the Ediacaran on the basis of chemostratigraphy and [[ichnofossil]]s are disputable.<ref name=Fedonkin2007/><ref name=Comments2004>Comments By B. S. Sokolov
column73: And M. A. Fedonkin. (2004) Appendix 2 in:""[http://www.stratigraphy.org/bak/ediacaran/Knoll_et_al_2004a.pdf The Ediacaran Period: A New Addition to the Geologic Time Scale.]""Submitted on Behalf of the Terminal Proterozoic Subcommission of the International Commission on Stratigraphy. pp. 32–34</ref>Cap carbonates generally have a restricted geographic distribution (due to specific conditions of their precipitation){{vague|date=June 2013}} and usually siliciclastic sediments replace laterally the cap carbonates in a rather short distance and cap carbonates do not occur above every tillite elsewhere{{clarify|reason=location not specified|date=May 2013}} in the world.The C-isotope chemostratigraphic characteristics obtained for contemporaneous cap carbonates in different parts of the world may be variable in a wide range owing to different degrees of secondary alteration of carbonates

P. 183.</ref>==Absolute dating==No [[Absolute dating|dating]] has been possible at the type section of the Ediacaran Period in South Australia.  Therefore the age range of 635 to 542 million years before the present is based on correlations to other countries where dating has been possible. The base age of approximately 635 million years ago is based on U-Pb ([[uranium]]-[[lead]]) [[isochron dating]] from [[Namibia]]<ref name=Hoffmann2004>{{cite journal| author = Hoffmann

column126: as more easily fossilized hard-shelled animals had yet to evolve. The Ediacaran biota include the oldest definite [[multicellular organism]]s with tissues
column127: and the most common types resemble segmented worms
column130: or immobile bags.Ediacara biota bear little resemblance to modern lifeforms
column131: and their [[biological classification|relationship]] even with the later lifeforms of the [[Cambrian explosion]] is rather difficult to interpret. More than 100 [[List of Ediacaran genera|genera]] have been described

column246: Kournikova was noted for her footspeed and aggressive baseline play
column247: and excellent angles and dropshots. however
column249: high-risk groundstrokes tended to produce frequent errors
column250: and her serve was sometimes unreliable in singles.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}}Kournikova plays right-handed with a two-handed [[backhand]].<ref name=""WTA""/>She is a great player at the net.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9407E0DD1339F934A1575BC0A960958260 | title = Substance Behind Those Shades  | accessdate =7 July 2008 | date = 27 August 1996| author = Selena Roberts | work = New York Times }}</ref>She can hit forceful groundstrokes and also [[drop shot]]s.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F07E0DF153BF932A15754C0A961958260 | work = New York Times | accessdate =7 July 2008 | date = 21 July 1997 | author = Ron Dicker | title = Rubin Defeats Kournikova in Exhibition Final }}</ref>Her playing style fits the profile for a doubles player
column251: and is complemented by her height.<ref name=""sweetannakournikova.com"">{{cite web|url=http://www.sweetannakournikova.com/bio.php |title=Sweet Anna Kournikova – Biography |publisher=Sweetannakournikova.com |date=7 June 1981 |accessdate=10 March 2012}}</ref>She has been compared to such doubles specialists as [[Pam Shriver]] and [[Peter Fleming (tennis player)|Peter Fleming]].<ref name=""sweetannakournikova.com""/>== Personal life ==Kournikova was in a relationship with fellow Russian [[Pavel Bure]]
column252: an [[National Hockey League|NHL]] [[ice hockey]] player. The two met in 1999 when Kournikova was still linked to Bure's former Russian teammate [[Sergei Fedorov]].<ref name=arbat>{{cite news |title=People: Courtney Love
column254: Antonio Moral |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/11/arts/11iht-peepsat.html |accessdate=12 July 2009 |date=11 February 2005 |work=The New York Times}}</ref>Bure and Kournikova were reported to have been engaged in 2000 after a reporter took a photo of them together in a Florida restaurant where Bure supposedly asked Kournikova to marry him. As the story made headlines in Russia
column255: where they were both heavily followed in the media as celebrities
column256: Bure and Kournikova both denied any engagement. Kournikova

column3: and ''[[Pulp Hero]]''. It is characterized by point-based character creation and the rigor with which it measures character abilities. It uses only six-sided [[dice]].==System features==The ''HERO System'' character creation system is entirely points-based with no random elements. Players are given a pool of points
column4: the size of which varies depending on the campaign type
column8: and Powers. They can gain additional points by taking Disadvantages that hamper their character in play.Abilities in the ''HERO System''
column9: particularly Powers (a broad category that includes superpowers
column13: are modeled based on their effects. The player chooses an effect the power models (such as Energy Blast) and chooses a set of modifiers to fine-tune the power's function. Each modifier makes the Power more or less expensive.Tasks are resolved using three six-sided dice and Power effects (especially damage) are resolved by rolling a number of dice based on the power's level.Unlike the [[d20 System]] and many other game systems
column14: experience awards are in the form of character points
column15: which have the same value as those used in character creation and can be applied directly to the character's abilities upon receipt.===Character creation===The ''HERO System'''s biggest innovation was its use of a point-based system for character creation with a tool-kit approach to creating abilities. The rules only define the ability's effects in combat—the player defines what the ability looks like when used.  For example
column16: the ability to project a jet of fire could be bought as""Energy Blast
column17: or any of a number of other abilities.  The player then defines it as a""jet of fire
column18: with all that implies: it has the possibility of starting secondary fires. it looks
column19: smells and sounds like a jet of fire. etc. This Energy Blast could be modified by any number of modifiers such as""Explosion
column20: "Area of Effect""or""No Range.""These affect how the power works as well as its final cost.Each player creates his character starting with a pool of points to buy abilities (such as the aforementioned""Energy Blast""and""Armor"")
column21: increase characteristics (such as""Strength""and""Intelligence"") and buy skills (such as""Computer Programming""and""Combat Driving"").  This pool can be increased by taking disadvantages for your character (such as being hunted by an enemy
column22: a dependency of some sort or having people who depend on your character in some way).  The initial pool
column23: as well as the final pool size
column25: as well as the point limits on each individual ability.===Advantages and disadvantages===The advantages of the ''HERO System ''are commonly{{Who|date=September 2010}} considered to be:#It eases [[game balance]] issues for the GM: characters of similar point totals are usually of roughly equal power.#It is very flexible in character creation
column26: allowing players to create nearly any character they can imagine.#It uses only six-sided [[dice]]
column27: as generally used in many board games.The primary disadvantages are commonly considered to be:#Complexity
column28: as character generation provides a sometimes overwhelming number of options and requires more mathematical computation than other games (but see [[#Mathematics issues|""Mathematics issues""]] below).#The great amount of time it can take to adjudicate combat.#The ability for players familiar with the system's quirks to use the system to decrease the point cost of powers
column29: leading to one character being much more powerful than another character of similar point value.#A large number of dice required at high power levelsThe""large number of dice required at high power levels""has been called both an advantage and a disadvantage.  The original designers
column31: have cited a""feeling of power""when rolling large numbers of dice and counting off huge amounts of damage.  On the other hand
column32: rolling such a large load of dice can be physically unwieldy and take a long time to add up.===Powers===The powers system is divided into a set of standard powers
column33: and a list of advantages and limitations that can be applied to each power. Many of the powers have specific advantages and limitations that apply only to that power. The powers in the HERO System are categorized roughly as follows::*'''Adjustment Powers''' — Modify the Characteristics of self or another.:*'''Attack Powers''' — Inflict physical damage or some other negative effect on an opponent.:*'''Body-Affecting Powers''' — Change shape
column36: etc.:*'''Defense Powers''' — Protect against an attack or mishap.:*'''Mental Powers''' — Detect and/or affect the mind of another.:*'''Movement Powers''' — Employ various forms of movement.:*'''Sense-Affecting Powers''' — Alter or hinder a character's senses.:*'''Sensory Powers''' — Improve or expand upon the sensory abilities.:*'''Size Powers''' — Growth and Shrinking.:*'''Special Powers''' — Powers with some unusual quality
column37: including ones that do not fall into the other categories.:*'''Standard Powers''' — A""catch-all""for Powers that are not Adjustment
column41: or Special Powers.Within each of these categories are multiple Powers that have more specialized effects. Thus for the movement category there are powers that can be used for [[Running]]
column48: and even [[Teleportation]]. For certain game [[genre]]s there are even powers for traveling to other dimensions or moving faster than light.Also
column49: many Powers appear in at least two categories.  For example
column50: most Attack Powers are also Standard Powers
column51: and Size Powers are basically just a subcategory of Body-Affecting Powers.  Darkness is in three categories — Standard
column53: and Sense-Affecting.====Point Cost====Each power has a base point cost for a given effect. This could be
column55: a certain number of points per six-sided-die (or""d6"") of damage inflicted upon a foe.Powers can have both advantages and limitations.  Both are modifiers applied at different stages in calculating cost.  These modifiers are typically changes of ±¼
column56: but can range up to ±2 or even higher.After the base cost is calculated
column58: which can make a power more useful
column59: typically expand its effectiveness or make it more powerful
column60: and thus make it more expensive.  Once advantages are applied
column61: the base cost becomes the Active Cost.The Active Cost is calculated as an intermediate step as it is required to calculate certain figures
column65: and other things.The formula for calculating the Active Cost is::'''Active Cost''' = '''Base Cost'''&times. (1 + ''Advantages'')Once Active Cost is calculated
column66: limitations are applied.  These represent shortcomings in the power
column67: lessened reliability or situations in which the power can not be used.  Limitations are added separately as positive numbers
column68: even though they are listed as negative.The Real Cost of the power is then determined by::'''Real Cost''' = '''Active Cost''' / (1 + ''Limitations'')The Real Cost is the amount the character must actually pay for the Power.====Power Frameworks====The rules also include schemes for providing a larger number of powers to a character for a given cost. These power frameworks reduce the cost either by requiring the group of powers to have a common theme as in an Elemental Control Framework
column69: or by limiting the number of powers that can be active at one time with a Multipower Framework. Powers within a framework can share common limitations
column70: further reducing the cost. A third type of power framework
column72: trades thrift for flexibility. With it
column73: powers can be arbitrarily chosen on the fly
column74: granting enhanced in-game flexibility. The price is a premium on points
column76: it is marked as potentially unbalancing
column77: so not all GMs will permit VPP's.Elemental Controls were eliminated in the Sixth Edition.===Mathematics issues===One of the criticisms leveled at the ''HERO System'' almost since its inception is the relatively large amount of computation involved in its use
column78: particularly during character creation. While almost none of this math goes beyond the basic functions of [[addition]]
column81: and [[division (mathematics)|division]] (certain obscure and completely optional situations ''may'' call for a [[logarithm]]ic function)
column82: this can seem daunting to newcomers.As a result
column83: [[software]] has been created to automate the bookkeeping involved.""Heromaker""
column85: was distributed with some versions of [[Champions (role-playing game)|Champions]]. Today
column86: Hero Designer""<ref>[http://www.herodesigner.com/home.htm""Hero Designer: Character creation software for HERO System
column88: vendor website</ref>for the Fifth and Sixth Editions is available on several platforms
column89: and is supported by numerous character packs and other extensions linked to Hero Games book releases.==Publishing history==''See also:''  [[List of Hero System Products]]Although several games based on the ''HERO System'' were published in the 1980s
column95: ''[[Robot Warriors]]'' and the original versions of ''[[Fantasy HERO]]'' and ''[[Star HERO]]''
column96: each of the RPGs was self-contained
column97: much as [[Chaosium]]'s [[Basic Role-Playing]] games are. The ''HERO System'' itself was not released as an independent entity until 1989
column98: as [[Steve Jackson Games]]' ''[[GURPS]]'' (''Generic Universal Roleplaying System'') became more popular. As a joint venture between Hero Games and [[Iron Crown Enterprises]]
column99: a stand-alone ''HERO System Rulebook'' was published alongside the fourth edition of Champions. The content was identical to the opening sections of the Champions rules
column100: but all genre-related material was removed. Afterward
column101: genre books such as ''Ninja HERO'' (written by [[Aaron Allston]]) and ''[[Fantasy HERO]]'' were published as sourcebooks for the ''HERO System Rulebook'' as opposed to being independent games.With the collapse of the Hero-ICE alliance
column102: the ''HERO System'' went into limbo for several years. ''The Champions'' franchise released a new version under the [[Fuzion]] system
column103: which had been a joint development with [[R. Talsorian Games]]
column104: called ''Champions: the New Millennium''. Although two editions were published
column105: it was very poorly received by ''Champions'' fans. In 2001
column106: a reconstituted Hero Games was formed under the leadership of [[Steven S. Long]]
column107: who had written several books for the earlier version of the system. It regained the rights to the ''HERO System'' and to the ''Champions'' trademark.In 2001
column108: the Fifth Edition of the ''HERO System Rulebook'' was released
column109: incorporating heavy revisions by Long. A large black hardcover
column110: it was critically well received and attained a degree of commercial success. (Following problems with fragile [[Bookbinding|bindings]] on Fourth Edition rulebooks
column111: the planned binding for the larger Fifth Edition was tested using a clothes dryer.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20051123133645/http://herogames.com/news/2002/0125.jsp""News""]
column114: 2002</ref>) The Fifth Edition is often referred to as""FREd""
column115: which is a [[backronym]] for""Fifth Rules Edition"". The name actually comes from Steve S. Long's reply when asked what the standard abbreviation for the Fifth Edition would be:""I don't care if you call it 'Fred'
column116: as long as you buy it.""A revised version (ISBN 1-58366-043-7) was issued in 2004
column118: a condensed version of the rulebook with a cover price of under $10. Fans often call the revised Fifth Edition""Fiver
column120: or""5ER""(from""Fifth Edition revised"".""Fiver""also alludes to ''[[Watership Down]]''). This rulebook is so big (592 pages) that some fans speculated that it might be bulletproof
column121: and it did indeed stop some bullets when tested by Hero Games staffers.<ref>[http://www.herogames.com/forums/showthread.php?t=54793""5ER Bulletproof Video""]
column123: Hero Games forum. Video hosted at [[YouTube]].</ref>On February 28

One of the new features will be to allow players to adapt their ''[[Champions Online]]'' characters to the pen-and-paper game.<ref name=""championspurchase"">{{cite web|url=http://crypticstudios.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=174&Itemid=32|title=Cryptic Studios Announces Champions Online|publisher=[[Cryptic Studios]]|quote=Cryptic Studios also announced today that it has acquired the ''Champions'' intellectual property (IP) from Hero Games. First published in 1981
column127: the ''Champions'' role-playing game is one of the first RPGs to forgo the traditional dice-rolling system of character generation in favor of a point-based system. Cryptic Studios has licensed back to Hero Games the rights to produce Champions RPG books
column128: and the sixth edition of the HERO System and ''Champions''
column130: will include rules on how to recreate Champions Online characters and scenarios.}}</ref>In late 2008
column131: Hero released a licensed RPG for [[Aaron Williams (cartoonist)|Aaron Williams]]'s popular comic [[PS238]] using a simplified version of the Fifth Edition rules.In late 2009
column132: Hero Games released the 6th Edition of the Hero System. The game has so far had a mostly positive reception
column133: with little in the way of 'Edition Wars'.Among other changes
column134: there are no Figured Characteristics - All Characteristics
column137: more minor rules changes include folding Armor and Force field into Resistant Defense and reestablishing Regeneration as a separate power. The rules were released in two volumes
column138: with the first covering character creation in depth and the second describing campaigns and the running of games. The new genre book for Champions came out shortly thereafter
column139: and a new ''Fantasy HERO'' was released in the summer of 2010. A new version of Sidekick was released in late 2009 under the title ''The HERO System Basic Rulebook''
column140: while an Advanced Player Guide was published that had additional options for character creation. Other recent releases included a large book of pre-constructed Powers
column141: a set of pre-generated Martial Arts styles
column144: a new [[grimoire]] for Fantasy Hero and a three-volume set of villains for ''Champions''. A new edition of ''Star HERO'' was released in 2011
column145: along with a second Advanced Player Guide.In 2011
column147: with long-time developer Steven S. Long relinquishing his full-time status to work freelance. In late 2012 ''Champions Complete'' was released
column148: which contained all of the core 6th edition rules as well as enough information to play a superhero campaign in a single 240-page book. This compact presentation reflected criticism that the 6th edition rules had become too unwieldy.Mirroring the shrinking of much of the table-top games industry
column149: Hero Games now maintains an irregular release schedule
column151: and has successfully used [[Kickstarter]] to raise funds for new projects. One of these new products
column153: was released in early 2015.==References==<references/>==External links==*[http://www.herogames.com/ HERO Games] Company website*{{dmoz|Games/Roleplaying/Genres/Universal/Hero_System}}{{Hero 5E}}{{RPG systems}}[[Category:Hero System| ]][[Category:Universal role-playing games]]"

column14: is a [[Private university|private]] [[Ivy League]] [[Doctoral university|research university]] located in [[Hanover
column16: United States. It consists of a liberal arts college
column20: as well as 19 graduate programs in the arts and sciences.<ref name=""usnwr-aag""/>Incorporated as the""Trustees of Dartmouth College
column21: <ref name=""charter""/>it is one of the nine [[List of Colonial Colleges|Colonial Colleges]] founded before the American Revolution.<ref name=""about-dartmouth-facts""/>With an undergraduate enrollment of 4
column22: 276 and a total student enrollment of 6
column24: Dartmouth is the smallest university in the Ivy League.<ref name=""2013 admissions""/>Dartmouth College was established in 1769 by [[Eleazar Wheelock]]
column25: a [[Congregational church|Congregational]] minister. After a long period of financial and political struggles
column26: Dartmouth emerged in the early 20th century from relative obscurity.<ref name=""trd-wheelock""/>Dartmouth's somewhat-isolated rural {{convert|269|acre|km2|adj=on}} campus is in the [[Upper Valley (Connecticut River)|Upper Valley]] region of New Hampshire. Participation in athletics and the school's [[Dartmouth College Greek organizations|Greek system]] is strong.<ref name=""abc-greek""/>Dartmouth's 34 varsity sports teams compete in the [[Ivy League]] conference of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] Division I. Students are well known for preserving a variety of strong campus traditions.<ref name=""A Frat Party Is:. a) Milk and Cookies. b) Beer Pong""/><ref name=""Hill Winds
column28: and Other Dartmouth Traditions""/><ref name=""Our Mission""/><ref name=""Dartmouth: Forever New An address by President James Wright: On the Occasion of his Inauguration as the 16th President of Dartmouth College""/>== History =={{See also|List of presidents of Dartmouth College}}Dartmouth was founded by [[Eleazar Wheelock]]
column31: who had previously sought to establish a school to train [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] as missionaries. Wheelock's ostensible inspiration for such an establishment resulted from his relationship with [[Mohegan]] Indian [[Samson Occom]]. Occom became an ordained minister after studying under Wheelock from 1743 to 1747
column32: and later moved to [[Long Island]] to preach to the [[Montaukett|Montauks]].<ref name=""history-lesson""/>Wheelock founded [[Moor's Charity School|Moor's Indian Charity School]] in 1755.<ref name=""Eleazar Wheelock's Two Schools""/>The Charity School proved somewhat successful
column33: but additional funding was necessary to continue school's operations
column34: and Wheelock sought the help of friends to raise money. Occom
column35: accompanied by the Reverend Nathaniel Whitaker
column36: traveled to England in 1766 to raise money from churches. With these funds
column37: they established a trust to help Wheelock.<ref name=""history-lesson""/>The head of the trust was a [[Methodist]] named [[William Legge
column38: 2nd Earl of Dartmouth]].[[File:Dartmouth College campus 2007-10-02 03 - Charter.jpg|thumb|upright|The Charter of Dartmouth College on display in [[Baker Memorial Library]]. The Charter was signed on December 13
column40: on behalf of [[George III of the United Kingdom|King George III of Great Britain]].]]Although the fund provided Wheelock ample financial support for the Charity School
column41: Wheelock had trouble recruiting Indians to the institution
column42: primarily because its location was far from tribal territories. In seeking to expand the school into a college
column44: in the [[Province of New Hampshire]]. The move from Connecticut followed a lengthy and sometimes frustrating effort to find resources and secure a charter. The Royal Governor of New Hampshire
column47: provided the land upon which Dartmouth would be built and on December 13
column49: issued the charter in the name of [[King George III]] establishing the College. That charter created a college""for the education and instruction of Youth of the Indian Tribes in this Land in reading
column50: writing&all parts of Learning which shall appear necessary and expedient for civilizing&christianizing Children of Pagans as well as in all liberal Arts and Sciences and also of English Youth and any others.""The reference to educating Native American youth was included to connect Dartmouth to the Charity School and enable use of the Charity School's unspent trust funds. Named for [[William Legge
column51: 2nd Earl of Dartmouth]]—an important supporter of Eleazar Wheelock's earlier efforts but who
column53: opposed creation of the College and never donated to it—Dartmouth is the nation's ninth oldest college and the last institution of higher learning established under Colonial rule.<ref name=""About Dartmouth&nbsp.– History""/>The College granted its first degrees in 1771.<ref name=""Eleazar Wheelock and the Adventurous Founding of Dartmouth College""/>Given the limited success of the Charity School
column55: Wheelock intended his new college as one primarily for whites.<ref name=""history-lesson""/><ref name=""chi""/>Occom
column56: disappointed with Wheelock's departure from the school's original goal of Indian [[Christianization]]
column57: went on to form his own community of New England Indians called [[Brothertown Indians]] in New York.<ref name=""history-lesson""/><ref name=""chi""/>[[File:Early Dartmouth Dunham.jpg|thumb|left|The earliest known image of Dartmouth appeared in the February 1793 issue of ''Massachusetts Magazine''. The engraving may also be the first visual proof of [[cricket]] being played in the United States.<ref name=""CricketRauner""/>]]In 1819
column58: Dartmouth College was the subject of the historic [[Dartmouth College v. Woodward|Dartmouth College case]]
column59: which challenged [[New Hampshire]]'s 1816 attempt to amend the college's royal charter to make the school a public university. An institution called [[Dartmouth University]] occupied the college buildings and began operating in Hanover in 1817
column60: though the college continued teaching classes in rented rooms nearby.<ref name=""history-lesson""/>[[Daniel Webster]]
column62: presented the College's case to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]]
column63: which found the amendment of Dartmouth's charter to be an [[Contract Clause|illegal impairment of a contract]] by the state and reversed New Hampshire's takeover of the college. Webster concluded his [[peroration]] with the famous words:""It is
column66: a small college. And yet there are those who love it.""<ref name=""history-lesson""/>Dartmouth emerged onto the national academic stage at the turn of the 20th century. Prior to this period
column67: the college had clung to traditional methods of instruction and was relatively poorly funded.<ref name=""trd-wheelock""/>Under President [[William Jewett Tucker]] (1893–1909)
column68: Dartmouth underwent a major revitalization of facilities
column71: following large endowments such as the $10
column72: 000 given by Dartmouth alumnus and law professor [[John Ordronaux (doctor)|John Ordronaux]].<ref name=""Many Bequests to Carity. Will of Dr. Ordronaux D...""/>20 new structures replaced antiquated buildings
column73: while the student body and faculty both expanded threefold. Tucker is often credited for having""refounded Dartmouth""and bringing it into national prestige.<ref name=""William Jewett Tucker""/>[[File:Dartmouth Hall.jpg|thumb|right|Lithograph of the President's House
column77: circa 1834]]Presidents [[Ernest Fox Nichols]] (1909–16) and [[Ernest Martin Hopkins]] (1916–45) continued Tucker's trend of modernization
column78: further improving campus facilities and introducing [[College admissions in the United States|selective admissions]] in the 1920s.<ref name=""trd-wheelock""/>[[John Sloan Dickey]]
column81: particularly [[public policy]] and [[international relations]].<ref name=""trd-wheelock""/><ref name=""John Sloan Dickey""/>During [[World War II]]
column82: Dartmouth was one of 131 colleges and universities nationally that took part in the [[V-12 Navy College Training Program]] which offered students a path to a navy commission.<ref name=""navyarchives-v-12""/>In 1970
column83: longtime professor of [[mathematics]] and [[computer science]] [[John George Kemeny]] became president of Dartmouth.<ref name=""kemeny-bio""/>Kemeny oversaw several major changes at the college. Dartmouth
column84: previously serving as a men's institution

Freedman""/>The first decade of the 21st century saw the commencement of the $1.3 billion Campaign for the Dartmouth Experience

Woodward]]'' and Dartmouth's successful self-reinvention in the late 19th century.<ref name=""Booz Allen Hamilton Lists the World's Most Enduring Institutions""/>Since the election of a number of petition-nominated trustees to the [[Board of Trustees of Dartmouth College|Board of Trustees]] starting in 2004

column130: and 2013 it ranked Dartmouth first in undergraduate teaching at national universities.<ref name=""usnews-rankings""/>It also ranked first in High School Counselor Rankings in 2012.<ref name=""usnews-rankings""/>The college ranks number seven in ''The Wall Street Journal'''s ranking of top feeder schools.<ref name=""WSJ Ranking the Colleges""/>The 2006 [[The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching|Carnegie Foundation]] classification listed Dartmouth as the only""majority-undergraduate""

column137: and 9.4% of applicants were admitted. Of those admitted whose high schools reported a [[class rank]]

Students from families with a combined annual income of less than $75

column150: a student must complete 35 total courses
column151: eight to ten of which are typically part of a chosen major program.<ref name=""requirements""/>Other requirements for graduation include the completion of ten""distributive requirements""in a variety of academic fields
column153: and completion of a writing class and first-year seminar in writing.<ref name=""requirements""/>Many departments offer honors programs requiring students seeking that distinction to engage in""independent

column160: Dartmouth grants doctorate and master's degrees in 19 Arts&Sciences graduate programs. Although the first graduate degree
column163: many of the current PhD programs have only existed since the 1960s.<ref name=""about-dartmouth-facts""/>Furthermore
column164: Dartmouth is home to three professional schools: the [[Geisel School of Medicine]] (established 1797)
column165: [[Thayer School of Engineering]] (1867)&nbsp.— which also serves as the undergraduate department of engineering sciences&nbsp.— and [[Tuck School of Business]] (1900). With these professional schools and graduate programs
column166: conventional American usage would accord Dartmouth the label of""Dartmouth University"".<ref name=""about-dartmouth-facts""/>however

column168: the school uses the name""Dartmouth College""to refer to the entire institution.<ref name=""history-lesson""/>Dartmouth employs a total of 607 tenured or tenure-track faculty members
column169: including the highest proportion of female tenured professors among the Ivy League universities.<ref name=""about-dartmouth-facts""/>Faculty members have been at the forefront of such major academic developments as the [[Dartmouth Conferences]]
column173: sponsored project awards to Dartmouth faculty research amounted to $169 million.<ref name=""Academics&Research""/>Dartmouth serves as the host institution of the [[University Press of New England]]
column174: a [[university press]] founded in 1970 that is supported by a consortium of schools that also includes [[Brandeis University]]
column177: [[Tufts University]] and the [[University of Vermont]].<ref name=""About UPNE""/>{{further2|[[List of Dartmouth College faculty]]}}=== The Dartmouth Plan ===[[File:BakerLibrary.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Baker Memorial Library]] at Dartmouth College]]Dartmouth functions on a quarter system
column178: operating year-round on four ten-week [[academic term]]s. The Dartmouth Plan (or simply""D-Plan"") is an academic scheduling system that permits the customization of each student's academic year. All undergraduates are required to be in residence for the fall
column180: and spring terms of their freshman and senior years
column181: as well as the summer term of their sophomore year.<ref name=""d-plan-admin""/>However
column182: students may petition to alter this plan so that they may be off during Freshman
column184: or sophomore Summer<ref name=""Petition for Change"">{{cite web|title=PETITION FOR CHANGE IN ENROLLMENT PATTERN|url=http://www.dartmouth.edu/~reg/docs/change_in_enrollment_pattern.pdf|website=http://www.dartmouth.edu/~reg/docs/change_in_enrollment_pattern.pdf|publisher=Dartmouth|accessdate=July 23
column186: students are permitted to choose between studying on-campus
column188: or taking a term off for vacation
column190: or research projects.<ref name=""d-plan-admin""/>The typical course load is three classes per term
column191: and students will generally enroll in classes for 12 total terms over the course of their academic career.<ref name=""Working Rules and Procedures""/>The D-Plan was instituted in the early 1970s at the same time that Dartmouth began accepting female undergraduates. It was initially devised as a plan to increase the enrollment without enlarging campus accommodations
column192: and has been described as""a way to put 4
column194: 000 beds.""<ref name=""trd-wheelock""/>Although new dormitories have been built since
column195: the number of students has also increased and the D-Plan remains in effect. It was modified in the 1980s in an attempt to reduce the problems of lack of social and academic continuity.=== Board of Trustees ==={{Main|Board of Trustees of Dartmouth College}}[[File:Dartmouth College campus 2007-06-23 Dartmouth Hall 02.JPG|thumb|right|Dartmouth Hall
column196: reconstructed in 1906]]Dartmouth is governed by a Board of Trustees comprising the college president (''ex officio'')
column197: the [[governor of New Hampshire|state governor]] (''ex officio'')
column198: 13 trustees nominated and elected by the board (called""charter trustees"")
column199: and eight trustees nominated by alumni and elected by the board (""alumni trustees"").<ref name=""Dartmouth Trustees vote to expand size of board""/>The nominees for alumni trustee are determined by a poll of the members of the Association of Alumni of Dartmouth College
column200: selecting from among names put forward by the Alumni Council or by alumni petition.Although the board elected its members from the two sources of nominees in equal proportions between 1891 and 2007
column201: <ref name=""Board of trustees vote to change how Dartmouth College is run""/>the board decided in 2007 to add several new members
column202: all charter trustees.<ref name=""Board adds 8 seats
column203: ends century-old parity""/>In the controversy that followed the decision

Eisenhower]]

column208: New Hampshire""/>}}Dartmouth College is situated in the rural town of [[Hanover
column210: located in the [[Upper Valley (Connecticut River)|Upper Valley]] along the [[Connecticut River]] in [[New England]]. Its {{convert|269|acre|km2|adj=on}} campus is centered on a {{convert|5|acre|adj=on|0}}""[[The Green (Dartmouth College)|Green]]""
column211: <ref name=""The Campus""/>a former field of [[pine|pine trees]] cleared in 1771.<ref name=""dartmo-green""/>Dartmouth is the largest private landowner of the town of Hanover
column212: <ref name=""Open Space Priorities Plan Summary""/>and its total landholdings and facilities are worth an estimated $434 million.<ref name=""irs""/>In addition to its campus in Hanover

column216: NH June 2011.jpg|thumb|left|American Elm on Dartmouth College campus
column217: June 2011]]Dartmouth's campus buildings vary in age from Wentworth and Thornton Halls of the 1820s (the oldest surviving buildings constructed by the college) to new dormitories and mathematics facilities completed in 2006.<ref name=""Kemeny Hall and Haldeman Center""/><ref name=""McLaughlin Cluster Residence Halls""/>Most of Dartmouth's buildings are designed in the [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]] [[American colonial architecture|American colonial]] style

column220: Dartmouth College.jpg|thumb|The Hopkins Center]]The college's creative and performing arts facility is the [[Hopkins Center for the Arts]] (""the Hop""). Opened in 1962
column221: the Hop houses the College's drama
column227: and jewelry studio which are open for use by students and faculty.<ref name=""hop-info""/>The building was designed by the famed architect [[Wallace Harrison]]

column229: arguably North America's oldest museum in continuous operation

column255: Baker's {{convert|200|ft|m|sing=on}} tower is an iconic symbol of the College.<ref name=""Baker Library Bell Tower""/><ref name=""No Bridge Left Unburned: Rage at Dartmouth""/><ref name=""nhspe""/>=== Athletic facilities ===[[File:Dartmouth College campus 2007-06-23 Memorial Field 02.JPG|thumb|[[Memorial Field (Dartmouth College)|Memorial Field]]]]Dartmouth's original sports field was [[The Green (Dartmouth College)|the Green]]
column256: where students played [[cricket]] and [[old division football]] during the 19th century.<ref name=""dartmo-green""/>Today
column257: two of Dartmouth's athletic facilities are located in the southeast corner of campus.<ref name=""dcaf""/>The center of athletic life is the [[Alumni Gymnasium (Dartmouth College)|Alumni Gymnasium]]
column258: which includes the Karl Michael Competition Pool and the Spaulding Pool
column259: a state of the art fitness center
column261: and a 1/13th-mile (123&nbsp.m) indoor track.<ref name=""Alumni Gym""/>Attached to Alumni Gymnasium is the Berry Sports Center
column262: which contains basketball and volleyball courts ([[Leede Arena]])
column263: as well as the Kresge Fitness Center.<ref name=""Berry Sports Center""/>Behind the Alumni Gymnasium is [[Memorial Field (Dartmouth)|Memorial Field]]
column265: 600-seat stadium overlooking Dartmouth's football field and track.<ref name=""Memorial Field""/>The nearby [[Thompson Arena]]
column266: designed by Italian engineer [[Pier Luigi Nervi]] and constructed in 1975
column267: houses Dartmouth's ice rink.<ref name=""Thompson Arena""/>Also visible from Memorial Field is the {{convert|91800|sqft|m2|adj=on}} Nathaniel Leverone Fieldhouse
column268: home to the indoor track. The new softball field
column271: sharing parking facilities with Thompson arena.Dartmouth's other athletic facilities in Hanover include the Friends of Dartmouth Rowing Boathouse and the old rowing house storage facility (both located along the Connecticut River)
column273: Dartmouth's oldest remaining athletic facility (established in 1899)
column274: <ref name=""History""/>and the Corey Ford Rugby Clubhouse.<ref name=""Rugby Fires It Up With New Clubhouse""/>The college also maintains the [[Dartmouth Skiway]]
column275: a {{convert|100|acre|km2|adj=on}} skiing facility located over two mountains near the Hanover campus in [[Lyme Center
column277: <ref name=""Dartmouth Skiway""/>that serves as the winter practice grounds for the nationally dominant Dartmouth ski team.=== Housing and student life facilities ===[[File:Dartmouth College campus 2007-06-23 Lord Hall.JPG|thumb|right|Lord Hall in the Gold Coast Cluster]]Instead of ungrouped dormitories or [[residential college]]s
column278: Dartmouth has nine residential communities located throughout campus.<ref name=""orl""/>The dormitories vary in design from modern to traditional Georgian styles
column279: and room arrangements range from singles to quads and apartment suites.<ref name=""orl""/>Since 2006
column280: the College has guaranteed housing for students during their freshman and sophomore years.<ref name=""Assembly reworks UFC membership guidelines""/>More than 3
column281: 000 students elect to live in housing provided by College.<ref name=""orl""/>Campus meals are served by Dartmouth Dining Services
column282: which operates 11 dining establishments around campus.<ref name=""Campus Map""/>Four of them are located at the center of campus in the Class of 1953 Commons
column283: formerly Thayer Dining Hall.<ref name=""Dining Locations""/>The Collis Center is the center of student life and programming
column284: serving as what would be generically termed the""student union""or""campus center.""<ref name=""Collis Center""/>It contains a café
column287: and a number of administrative departments
column288: including the [[Dartmouth College Academic Skills Center|Academic Skills Centre]].<ref name=""Collis Floor Plans""/><ref name=""Administrative Departments in Collis Center""/>Robinson Hall
column289: next door to both Collis and Thayer
column290: contains the offices of a number of student organizations including the [[Dartmouth Outing Club]] and ''[[The Dartmouth]]'' daily newspaper.<ref name=""Robinson Hall""/>=== Trees and grounds ===A notable feature of the Dartmouth campus is its many trees
column291: particularly [[Ulmus americana|American elms]].<ref>{{cite web| title=Old Growth - Dartmouth's elms endure as defining features of the campus| url=http://www.dartmouth.edu/~dartlife/archives/17-3/elms.html| website=Dartmouth College website
column292: Dartmouth Life Home| accessdate=2014-12-26| date=June 2007| quote=The College's claim on the landscape began with the felling of the great white pines that grew on the plain above the Connecticut River. planting came later. By the middle of the 19th century
column293: villages and towns throughout New England—and eventually across the nation—were shading their streets with the American elm
column294: Ulmus americana. A circa 1840 watercolor image of the College depicts graceful young elms edging the Green.""If you look at pictures of old Hanover

column297: Main Street and College Street were completely lined with elms

column300: the elm trees at Dartmouth have been affected by [[Dutch elm disease]] and damaged by storms and other environmental conditions. However
column301: because the college is committed to maintaining the campus aesthetic
column303: and new plantings replace diseased or damaged trees that must be removed.<ref>{{cite web| title=Old Growth - Dartmouth's elms endure as defining features of the campus| url=http://www.dartmouth.edu/~dartlife/archives/17-3/elms.html| website=Dartmouth College website

column352: the [[fraternities and sororities in North America|Greek system]] dating from the 1840s is one of the most popular social outlets for students.<ref name=""abc-greek""/><ref name=""Halls
column353: Tombs and Houses: Student Society Architecture at Dartmouth""/>Dartmouth is home to 32 recognized Greek houses: 17 fraternities
column358: roughly 70% of eligible students belonged to a Greek organization.<ref name=""Transgenders try to navigate Greek system""/>since 1987
column359: students have not been permitted to join Greek organizations until their sophomore year.<ref name=""History of CFS Organizations at Dartmouth""/>Dartmouth College was among the first institutions of higher education to [[desegregate]] fraternity houses in the 1950s
column360: and was involved in the movement to create [[coeducational]] Greek houses in the 1970s.<ref name=""The College on the Hill: A Dartmouth Chronicle""/>In the early first decade of the 21st century

column362: leading to police raids and accusations of [[sexual harassment]].<ref>Janet Reitman
