column370: 2013</ref>Dartmouth also has a number of secret societies
column371: which are student- and alumni-led organizations often focused on preserving the history of the college and initiating service projects. Most prominent among them is the [[Sphinx (senior society)|Sphinx society]]
column372: housed in a prominent Egyptian tomb-like building near the center of campus. The Sphinx has been the subject of numerous rumors as to its facilities

column376: 2014|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>The college has an additional classification of social/residential organizations known as [[Dartmouth College student groups#Undergraduate societies|undergraduate societies]].<ref name=""Senior and Undergraduate Society Administration""/>=== Athletics ==={{Main|Dartmouth Big Green}}[[File:Darthmouth vs Princeton 1.jpg|thumb|left|A Dartmouth varsity hockey game against Princeton at [[Thompson Arena]]]]Approximately 20% of students participate in a varsity sport
column377: and nearly 80% participate in some form of club
column380: or other athletics.<ref name=""What percentage of Dartmouth students play a varsity sport?""/>In 2007
column381: Dartmouth College fielded 34 intercollegiate varsity teams: 16 for men
column383: and coeducational sailing and equestrian programs. Dartmouth's athletic teams compete in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] eight-member [[Ivy League]] conference. some teams also participate in the [[Eastern College Athletic Conference]] (ECAC).<ref name=""about-dartmouth-athletics""/>As is mandatory for the members of the Ivy League
column384: Dartmouth College does not offer athletic scholarships.<ref name=""about-dartmouth-athletics""/><ref name=""What is the Ivy League?""/>In addition to the traditional American team sports (football
column388: Dartmouth competes at the varsity level in many other sports including track and field
column394: and lacrosse.<ref name=""about-dartmouth-facts""/>The college also offers 26 club and intramural sports such as fencing
column402: leading to a 75% participation rate in athletics among the undergraduate student body.<ref name=""about-dartmouth-facts""/><ref name=""Club Sports""/>The Dartmouth Fencing Team
column404: won the [[USACFC]] club national championship in 2014.<ref>http://thedartmouth.com/2014/04/10/club-fencing-takes-first-national-title/</ref>The Dartmouth Men's Rugby Team
column406: has been ranked among the best collegiate teams in that sport over many years. The figure skating team won the national championship five straight times from 2004 through 2008.<ref name=""Dartmouth Wins Fourth Consecutive National Title""/>In addition to the academic requirements for graduation
column407: Dartmouth requires every undergraduate to complete a {{convert|50|yd|m|sing=on}} swim and three terms of [[physical education]].<ref name=""General Academic Requirements for Graduation""/>=== Technology ===[[File:Dartmouth College campus 2007-09-24 Baker-Berry Library 02.JPG|thumb|right|Students at a bank of Blitz terminals in Baker-Berry Library]]Technology plays an important role in student life
column408: as Dartmouth has been ranked as one of the most technologically advanced colleges in the world (as in ''[[Newsweek]]'''s 2004 ranking of""Hottest for the Tech-Savvy""<ref name=""newsweek""/>and [[Yahoo!]]'s 1998""Wired Colleges""list<ref name=""About BlitzMail""/>). [[BlitzMail]]
column410: plays a tremendous role in social life
column411: as students tend to use it for communication in lieu of [[cellular phones]] or [[instant messaging]] programs.<ref name=""Cell phones make inroads on Blitz-centric College campus""/><ref name=""nyt-blitz""/>Student reliance on BlitzMail (known colloquially as""Blitz
column412: which functions as both noun and verb<ref name=""nyt-blitz""/>) is reflected by the presence of about 100 public computer terminals intended specifically for BlitzMail use.<ref name=""nyt-blitz""/>Since 1991
column413: Dartmouth students have been required to own a personal computer.<ref name=""Students required to get wired""/><ref name=""All Students Required to Own a Computer""/>In 2001
column414: Dartmouth became the first Ivy League institution to offer entirely ubiquitous wireless internet access.<ref name=""newsweek""/>With over 1
column416: the network is available throughout all college buildings as well as in most public outdoor spaces.<ref name=""Computing at Dartmouth""/>Other technologies being pioneered include College-wide Video-on-Demand and VoIP rollouts.<ref name=""Computing at Dartmouth""/><ref name=""Dartmouth Public Affairs""/>=== Native Americans at Dartmouth ===It is often pointed out that the charter of Dartmouth College
column418: proclaims that the institution was created""for the education and instruction of Youth of the Indian Tribes in this Land in reading
column419: writing and all parts of Learning... as well as in all liberal Arts and Sciences. and also of English Youth and any others.""<ref name=""charter""/>However
column420: Wheelock primarily intended the college to educate White youth
column421: and the few Native students that attended Dartmouth experienced much difficulty in an institution ostensibly dedicated to their education.  The funds for the Charity School for Native Americans that preceded Dartmouth College were raised primarily by the efforts of a Native American named [[Samson Occom]]
column422: and at least some of those funds were used to help found the college.<ref name=""about-nap""/>The college graduated only 19 Native Americans during its first two hundred years.<ref name=""about-nap""/>In 1970
column423: the college established Native American academic and social programs as part of a""new dedication to increasing Native American enrollment.""<ref name =""about-nap""/>Since then
column424: Dartmouth has graduated over 700 Native American students from over 200 different tribes
column425: more than the other seven Ivy League universities combined.<ref name=""about-nap""/>=== Traditions ==={{Main|Dartmouth College traditions}}[[File:2004 Winter Carnival Sculpture.JPG|thumb|upright|Snow sculpture at the 2004 Dartmouth Winter Carnival]]Dartmouth is well known for its fierce school spirit and many traditions.<ref name=""15th President Installed at Dartmouth""/>The college functions on a [[Academic term|quarter system]]
column426: and one weekend each term is set aside as a traditional celebratory event
column427: known on campus as""big weekends""<ref name=""steph""/><ref name=""The Dartmouth Green: A Walking Tour of Dartmouth""/>or""party weekends"".<ref name=""Hopkins Center offers many alternatives over weekend""/>In the fall term
column428: Homecoming (officially called Dartmouth Night) is marked by a [[bonfire]] on the Green constructed by the freshman class.<ref name=""homecoming-history""/>Winter term is celebrated by Winter Carnival
column429: a tradition started in 1911 by the Dartmouth Outing Club to promote winter sports.<ref name=""tdr-wc""/>In the spring
column430: Green Key is a weekend mostly devoted to campus parties and celebration.<ref name=""Green Key History: Those Were the Days""/>The summer term was formerly marked by Tubestock
column431: an unofficial tradition in which the students used wooden rafts and inner tubes to float on the [[Connecticut River]]. Begun in 1986
column432: Tubestock met its demise in 2006 when Hanover town ordinances and a lack of coherent student protest conspired to defeat the popular tradition.<ref name=""Town
column433: College Weigh Tubestock Changes""/>The Class of 2008
column434: during their summer term on campus in 2006
column435: replaced the defunct Tubestock with Fieldstock. This new celebration includes a barbecue
column437: and the revival of the 1970s and 1980s tradition of racing homemade chariots around the Green. Unlike Tubestock
column438: Fieldstock is funded and supported by the College.<ref name=""Fieldstock
column439: chariots await town approval""/>Another longstanding tradition is four-day
column440: student-run [[Dartmouth Outing Club]] trips for incoming freshmen
column441: begun in 1935. Each trip concludes at the [[Moosilauke Ravine Lodge]].<ref name=""About the Program""/>In 2011
column442: over 96% of freshmen elected to participate.== Insignia and other representations ===== Motto and song ===Dartmouth's motto
column444: is ''Vox clamantis in deserto''. The Latin motto is literally translated as""The voice of one crying in the wilderness""
column445: <ref name=""Out of the Woods""/><ref name=""good""/>but is more often rendered as""A voice crying in the wilderness""
column446: <ref name=""Daily Debriefing""/>which attempts to translate the [[synecdoche]] of the phrase. The phrase appears five times in the Bible and is a reference to the college's location on what was once the frontier of European settlement.<ref name=""good""/><ref name=""Bartlett Hall's Wheelock Memorial Window""/>Richard Hovey's""[[Alma Mater (Dartmouth College)|Men of Dartmouth]]""was elected as the best of Dartmouth's songs in 1896
column447: <ref name=""homecoming-history""/>and became the school's official song in 1926.<ref name=""Follow-up on the news. Song out of tune with the times""/>The song was retitled to""Alma Mater""in the 1980s when its lyrics were changed to refer to women as well as men.<ref name=""rscl""/>=== Seal ==={{Main|Seal of Dartmouth College}}[[File:Seal of Dartmouth College.png|thumb|upright|left|Seal of Dartmouth College]]Dartmouth's 1769 royal charter required the creation of a [[seal (emblem)|seal]] for use on official documents and diplomas.<ref name=""charter""/>The college's founder [[Eleazar Wheelock]] designed a seal for his college bearing a striking resemblance to the seal of the [[USPG|Society for the Propagation of the Gospel]]
column448: a missionary society founded in London in 1701
column449: in order to maintain the illusion that his college was more for mission work than for higher education.<ref name=""good""/>Engraved by a Boston silversmith
column450: the seal was ready by commencement of 1773. The trustees officially accepted the seal on August 25
column453: circumscribed by a Line containing SIGILL: COL: DARTMUTH: NOV: HANT: IN AMERICA 1770. within projecting a Pine Grove on the Right
column454: whence proceed Natives towards an Edifice two Storey on the left. which bears in a Label over the Grove these Words""vox clamantis in deserto""the whole supported by Religion on the Right and Justice on the Left
column455: and bearing in a Triangle irradiate

column459: and all other Affairs of Business of and concerning Dartmouth College.<ref name=""collections""/>}}On October 28

A. Dwiggins]] to create a line drawing version of the seal in 1940 that saw widespread use. Dwiggins' design was modified during 1957 to change the date from""1770""to""1769""
column462: to accord with the date of the college charter. The trustees commissioned a new set of dies with a date of""1769""to replace the old dies
column463: now badly worn after almost two hundred years of use.<ref name=""good""/>The 1957 design continues to be used under trademark number 2305032.<ref name=""uspatent""/>=== Shield ===On October 28
column465: the trustees approved a""Dartmouth College Shield""for general use. Artist and engraver W. Parke Johnson designed this emblem on the basis of the shield that is depicted at the center of the original seal. This design does not survive. On June 9
column467: the trustees approved another [[coat of arms]] based on the shield part of the seal
column468: this one by Canadian artist and designer [[Thoreau MacDonald]]. That design was used widely and
column470: had its date changed from""1770""to""1769""around 1958.<ref name=""good""/>That version continues to be used under trademark registration number 3112676 and others.<ref name=""uspatent""/>College designer John Scotford made a stylized version of the shield during the 1960s
column471: but it did not see the success of MacDonald's design.<ref name=""A Proposal for a Heraldic Coat of Arms for Dartmouth College""/>The shield appears to have been used as the basis of the shield of [[Dartmouth Medical School]]
column472: and it has been reproduced in sizes as small as 20 micrometers across.<ref name=""Nanometer Pattern Generation System: Dartmouth Seal""/>The design has appeared on [[Rudolph Ruzicka]]'s Bicentennial Medal ([[Philadelphia Mint]]
column475: and mascot ===Dartmouth has never had an official [[mascot]].<ref name=""ad-green""/>The nickname""The Big Green

column5: meaning that the [[GPL]] permits combination and redistribution with software that uses the MIT License.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gnu.org/licenses/license-list.html#GPLCompatibleLicenses |title=Various Licenses and Comments about Them |accessdate=17 July 2013 |publisher=Free Software Foundation }}</ref>Notable [[Computer software|software packages]] that use one of the versions of the MIT License include [[Expat (XML)|Expat]]

column40: except that the BSD license contains a notice prohibiting the use of the name of the copyright holder in promotion.  This is sometimes present in versions of the MIT License
column41: as noted above.The original BSD license also includes a clause requiring all advertising of the software to display a notice crediting its authors. This""advertising clause""(since disavowed by UC Berkeley<ref name=update>{{cite web|url=ftp://ftp.cs.berkeley.edu/pub/4bsd/README.Impt.License.Change|title=To All Licensees
column42: Distributors of Any Version of BSD|publisher=University of California
column43: Berkeley|date=1999-07-22|accessdate=2006-11-15}}</ref>) is present in the modified MIT License used by [[XFree86 License|XFree86]].The MIT License states more explicitly the rights given to the [[end-user]]
column51: and/or sell the software. The MIT license specifically grants the right to""sublicense""in the text of the license itself — a right not mentioned in the BSD license which simply grants the right to""redistribute and use.""The right to sublicense means that the party that receives code under the MIT license grant has the legal right to grant all license rights it received downstream to a third party to whom that licensee distributes the MIT code.<ref>Dictionary.com defines""sublicense""as""a license or contract granted to a third party by a licensee for specified rights or uses of a product
column54: etc.""http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/sublicense</ref>{{better source|date=December 2014}}Like the BSD license the MIT license does not include an express patent license. Both the BSD and the MIT licenses were drafted before the patentability of software was generally recognized under US law.<ref>Stern and Allen
column56: p. 495 in Understanding the Intellectual Property License 2013 (Practicing Law Institute 2013)</ref>The MIT license contains terms that are used in defining the rights of a patent holder in 35 U.S Code section 154 namely""use
column57: and""sell.""This has been construed by some commentators<ref>Christian H. Nadan
column58: Closing the Loophole. Open Source Licensing and the Implied Patent License
column61: No. 8 (Aug. 2009) available at http://www.scribd.com/doc/46088081/Closing-the-Loophole-Open-Source-Licensing-and-the-Implied-Patent-License-Nadan who argues that “By using patent terms like “deal in
column64: ” the MIT license grant is more likely to be deemed to include express patent rights than the BSD license.</ref>35 U.S. Code section 154 defines the right of a patent holder as follow:""Every patent shall contain a short title of the invention and a grant to the patentee
column66: of the right to exclude others from making
column69: or selling the invention throughout the United States or importing the invention into the United States...""<ref>35 U.S. Code section 154 at http://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/35/154. Stern and Allen
column71: p. 495</ref>The nature of the right conferred by a U.S. patent is not obvious at first
column72: because it is a negative right
column73: the key is in the words""right to exclude.""<ref>Bitlaw
column74: 1996-2013 Daniel A. Tysver (Beck&Tysver) http://www.bitlaw.com/patent/rights.html</ref>Any person is ordinarily free to make
column77: and a grant do so is not needed. What a patent holder has is the right to exclude others from doing what they normally are free to do. So the inclusion of the words granting the right to""use""and""sell""can be construed as meaning no more than the licensee has all the rights they would normally have under a copyright grant. There is no need to infer that these commonly used words mean that the licensor was waiving its patent right to exclude others from such activity (and indeed presumes that the licensor had any such patent rights to exclude to begin with). Whether or not a court might imply a patent grant under the MIT license therefore remains an open question.The [[Simplified BSD license]] used by [[FreeBSD]] is essentially identical{{Citation needed|date=January 2014}}{{discuss|tag not related to statement}} to the MIT License
column78: as it contains neither an advertising clause
column79: nor a prohibition on promotional use of the copyright holder's name.Also similar in terms is the [[ISC license]]
column80: which has simpler language.The [[University of Illinois/NCSA Open Source License]] combines text from both the MIT and BSD licenses. the license grant and disclaimer are taken from the MIT License.==See also==* [[:Category:Software using the MIT license]]* [[Comparison of free and open-source software licenses]]{{Portal|Free software}}==References=={{Reflist}}==External links==* [https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Licensing:MIT?rd=Licensing/MIT MIT License variants]* [http://www.opensource.org/licenses/MIT The MIT License template] (Open Source Initiative official site)* [http://www.jclark.com/xml/copying.txt Expat License]* [http://www.xfree86.org/3.3.6/COPYRIGHT2.html#3 X11 License]{{FOSS}}{{DEFAULTSORT:Mit License}}[[Category:Free and open-source software licenses]][[Category:X Window System]][[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]"

column81: [[UK hard house|United Kingdom]]| other_topics = [[List of house artists|Notable artists and DJs]]}}'''House music''' is a genre of [[electronic dance music]] that originated in [[Chicago]] in the early 1980s. It was initially popularized in Chicago
column82: circa 1984. House music quickly spread to other American cities like Detroit
column84: and Newark - all of which developed their own regional scenes. In the mid-to-late 1980s
column85: house music became popular in Europe as well as major cities in South America
column86: and Australia.<ref name=unesco_4>{{cite journal | url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0012/001201/120152e.pdf | title=The club DJ: a brief history of a cultural icon | publisher=UNESCO | date=July–August 2000 | last=Fikentscher | first=Kai | journal=UNESCO Courier | page=47 | quote=Around 1986/7
column87: after the initial explosion of house music in [[Chicago]]
column88: it became clear that the major recording companies and media institutions were reluctant to market this genre of music
column90: on a mainstream level. House artists turned to Europe
column91: chiefly London but also cities such as Amsterdam
column96: and Tel Aviv.&nbsp.... A third axis leads to Japan where
column98: New York club DJs have had the opportunity to play guest-spots.}}</ref>Early house music commercial success in Europe saw songs such as""[[Pump Up the Volume (song)|Pump Up The Volume]]""by [[MARRS]] (1987)
column99: House Nation""by House Master Boyz and the Rude Boy of House (1987)
column100: [[Theme from S'Express]]""by [[S'Express]] (1988) and""[[Doctorin' the House]]""by [[Coldcut]] (1988) in the pop charts. Since the early to mid-1990s
column101: house music has been infused in mainstream [[Pop music|pop]] and [[dance music]] worldwide.Early house music was generally dance-based music characterized by repetitive [[Four on the floor (music)|4/4]] beats
column106: and synthesized basslines. While house displayed several characteristics similar to [[disco]] music
column107: it was more electronic and minimalistic
column108: <ref name=""allmusic""/>and the repetitive rhythm of house was more important than the song itself. House music in the 2010s
column109: while keeping several of these core elements
column110: notably the prominent [[kick drum]] on every beat
column111: varies a lot in style and influence
column112: ranging from the soulful and atmospheric [[deep house]] to the more minimalistic [[microhouse]]. House music has also fused with several other genres creating fusion subgenres
column115: [[electro house]] and [[Jump House (music genre)|jump house]].In the late 1980s
column116: many local Chicago house music artists suddenly found themselves presented with major label deals. House music proved to be a commercially successful genre and a more mainstream [[popular music|pop-based]] variation grew increasingly popular. Artists and groups such as [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]

column311: and find a better place for this-->House also had an influence of relaying political messages to people who were considered to be outcasts of society. The music appealed to those who didn't fit into mainstream American society and was especially celebrated by many black males. Frankie Knuckles once said that the Warehouse club in Chicago was like""church for people who have fallen from grace""The house producer Marshall Jefferson compared it to""old-time religion in the way that people just get happy and screamin'"".<ref name=""Reynolds2013"">{{cite book|author=Simon Reynolds|title=Generation Ecstasy: Into the World of Techno and Rave Culture|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=bAvy3S242wQC&pg=PA30|date=2013-06-19|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-78317-3|pages=30–}}</ref>Deep house was similar to many of the messages of freedom for the black community.==Regional scenes (1980s&ndash.1990s)=====Detroit sound: 1986&ndash.1989==={{main|Detroit techno|Techno}}Detroit techno is an offshoot of Chicago house music. column465: they began to create the standards that would shape all house music.==21st century=={{Section OR|date=May 2012}}===2000s==={{See also|Electroclash|Electro house}}Chicago Mayor [[Richard M. Daley]] proclaimed August 10
column467: in celebration of the""21st anniversary of house music""(actually the 21st anniversary of the founding of [[Trax Records]]
column468: an independent Chicago-based house label). The proclamation recognized Chicago as the original home of house music and that the music's original creators""were inspired by the love of their city
column469: with the dream that someday their music would spread a message of peace and unity throughout the world"". DJs such as [[Frankie Knuckles]]
column471: [[Paul Johnson (DJ)|Paul Johnson]] and [[Mickey Oliver]] celebrated the proclamation at the Summer Dance Series
column472: an event organized by Chicago's Department of Cultural Affairs.<ref>{{cite journal |date=2005-08-03 |title=Chicago Mayor Declares 'House Unity Day' |url=http://remixmag.com/transmissions/chicago-house-080405/ |journal=Remix |publisher=Penton Media
column473: Inc. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090917031408/http://remixmag.com/transmissions/chicago-house-080405/ |archivedate=2009-09-17}}</ref>{{Listen|filename=Electro House Loop.ogg|title=Electro house loop|description=This short loop demonstrates the style of a modern [[electro house]] track
column474: including a house beat and""dirty""bass.|pos=right}}It was during this decade that vocal house became firmly established
column475: both in the underground and as part of the pop market
column477: Roule and Om were at the forefront of championing the emerging sound. In the mid-2000s
column478: fusion genres such as [[electro house]] and [[fidget house]] emerged.{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}} This fusion is apparent in the crossover of musical styles by artists such as [[Dennis Ferrer]] and [[Booka Shade]]
column479: with the former's production style having evolved from the New York soulful house scene and the latter's roots in [[techno]].Numerous live performance events dedicated to house music were founded during the course of the decade
column480: including [[Shambhala Music Festival]] and major industry sponsored events like Miami's [[Winter Music Conference]]. The genre even gained popularity in the [[Middle East]] in cities such as [[Dubai]]&[[Abu Dhabi]]{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} and at events like [[Creamfields]].In the late 2000s
column481: house witnessed renewed chart success thanks to acts such as [[Daft Punk]]
column486: and [[Dada Life]].===2010s==={{Unreferenced section|date=January 2015}}{{See also|Electro house|Progressive house}}[[File:Swedish House Mafia and Benny Benassi.jpg|thumb|[[Swedish House Mafia]] performing in 2011.]]2010s saw multiple new sounds in house music developed by numerous DJs. Sweden knew a prominence of snare-less""Swedish [[progressive house]]""with the emergence of [[Sebastian Ingrosso]]
column488: [[Steve Angello]] (These three formed a trio called [[Swedish House Mafia]])
column491: etc. Netherlands brought together a concept of""Dirty Dutch""
column492: [[electro house]] subgenre characterized by very abrasive leads and darker arpeggios
column504: fusion genres derivative of 2000s progressive house returned to prominence
column505: especially with the help of DJs [[Calvin Harris]]
column512: [[Porter Robinson]] and [[Wolfgang Gartner]] in the US and Canada. The growing popularity of such artists led to the emergence of electro house and progressive house blended sounds in popular music
column513: such as singles [[Lady Gaga]]'s""[[Marry the Night]]""
column514: [[The Black Eyed Peas]]'""[[The Best One Yet (The Boy)]]""and the [[will.i.am]] and [[Britney Spears]]""[[Scream&Shout]]"". Big room house found increasing popularity since 2010
column515: particularly through international dance music festivals such as [[Tomorrowland (festival)|Tomorrowland]]
column517: and [[Electric Daisy Carnival]].In addition to these popular examples of house
column518: there has also been a reunification of contemporary house and its roots. Many hip hop and R&B artists also turn to house beats to add a mass appeal to the music they produce. Examples include Kelly Rowland's""Love Takes Over""feat. David Guetta
column519: Rihanna's""We Found Love""feat. Calvin Harris and Kid Cudi's""Memories""also feat. David Guetta.[[Deep House]] surged onto the UK Top 40 in 2014 with artists such as [[Duke Dumont]] and [[Secondcity]] earning number 1 hits with the sound
